title: 112_hr3829
content: The "Childcare Accountability and Responsibility Act of 2012" or the "CARE for Kids Act of 2012" requires a criminal background check for child care providers under the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990. The "CARE for Kids Act of 2012" mandates a criminal background check for child care staff and providers, including a search of the National Sex Offender Registry. The Adam Walsh Child Protection and Safety Act of 2006 requires background checks for individuals working with children, including searches of national and state criminal registries, as well as abuse and neglect databases. The Adam Walsh Child Protection and Safety Act of 2006 mandates background checks for child care providers, including searches of national and state criminal registries, abuse and neglect databases, and FBI fingerprint checks. Providers will be ineligible for funds if a staff member or resident has a criminal background. The Adam Walsh Child Protection and Safety Act of 2006 requires background checks for child care providers, including searching for felony convictions related to child abuse, spousal abuse, crimes against children, violent crimes, and distribution of illegal substances. The Adam Walsh Child Protection and Safety Act of 2006 mandates background checks for child care providers, including felony convictions for offenses like sexual assault, homicide, and drug-related crimes within 5 years prior to a criminal background check submission. The Child Care Accountability and Responsibility Act of 2012 requires background checks for child care staff and providers every 5 years, starting when the state implements the requirements. The Child Care Accountability and Responsibility Act of 2012 mandates background checks every 5 years for child care staff, providers, and adults residing in their private residence. The Child Care Accountability and Responsibility Act of 2012 requires background checks every 5 years for child care staff, providers, and adults living in their private residence. Not more than 1 request can be made. The Child Care Accountability and Responsibility Act of 2012 mandates background checks every 5 years for child care staff, providers, and adults residing in their private residence. Only one request is needed for a State and national criminal background check within each 5-year period. Results must be provided within 10 business days of the request. After a request is made for a State and national criminal background check, the appropriate State agency must provide the results to the requester. Upon request, a child care provider or individual subject to a background check can receive a copy of the check conducted under this section. Upon request, a State must provide a copy of the criminal background check conducted under this section. The State is required to ensure the accuracy and completeness of the information by obtaining dispositions of arrests older than 1 year and correcting any known inaccuracies. Upon request, a child care provider must complete a background check, ensuring accuracy by correcting inaccurate information, completing incomplete entries, and taking necessary steps to improve accuracy. Appeals must be made within 30 days of receiving the results of the background check. After completing a background check, a child care provider or individual can appeal the results to the State agency. The State must make a final ruling within 30 days, determining eligibility and providing specific findings to the individual. The State must provide specific findings to the individual appealing a background check, make necessary changes to the criminal record if inaccurate, and report these changes. A State may collect one fee per criminal background check from child care providers or families to cover costs. A State can charge a fee for criminal background checks on child care providers, not exceeding $36 in total. States must comply with the requirements within 3 years of the Childcare Accountability and Responsibility Act of 2012. The Secretary can grant extensions if needed. The Childcare Accountability and Responsibility Act of 2012 allows the Secretary to grant a 2-year extension to States making a good faith effort to meet the requirements. Definitions include 'adult' as a person over 18 and 'child care provider' as various types of child care services. A child care provider is a center-based or group home provider of child care services for compensation, not related to all children, and licensed or regulated under State law. A child care staff member is an individual providing child care services. The term 'child care staff member' refers to an individual who provides child care services for compensation on a regular basis, excluding those related to the children in their care. 'Family child care provider' is an individual who offers child care services for fewer than 24 hours per day as the sole caregiver in a private setting. The term 'care provider' refers to an individual who provides child care services for fewer than 24 hours per day, not related to all children in their care, and licensed, regulated, or registered under State law. Authorization of appropriations is provided to conduct criminal background checks. Authorization of appropriations is provided to conduct State and national criminal background checks to offset administrative costs.
